raw_text: However, as various researchers have pointed out (Harabagiu et al, 1999), these net works lack information, in particular with regard to syntagmatic associations, which are generally unsystematic

raw_text: Work on the Extended WordNet project (Harabagiu et al, 1999) is achieving subs tan tial progress in making the information in WordNet more explicit
clean_text: Work on the Extended WordNet project (Harabagiu et al, 1999) is achieving substantial progress in making the information in WordNet more explicit.

raw_text: For example, in eXtended WordNet (Harabagiu et al 1999), the rich glosses in WordNet are enriched by disambiguating the nouns, verbs, adverbs, and adjectives with synsets

raw_text: In the sections to follow we describe a mechanism for automating the extraction of these relationships (in the same vein as (Harabagiu et al 1999), and for using them to generative apt interpretations for metaphors involving WordNet entries

raw_text: Harabagiu et al (1999) proposed a scheme for attaching sense tags to predicates within the frame work of transforming WordNet glosses into a logical form
clean_text: Harabagiu et al (1999) proposed a scheme for attaching sense tags to predicates within the framework of transforming WordNet glosses into a logical form.

raw_text: Endeavors such as that of Harabagiu et al (1999), in which each of the textual glosses in Word Net (Fellbaum, 1998) is linguistically analyzed to yield a sense-tagged logical form, is an example of the former approach

raw_text: For example, in eXtended WordNet (Harabagiu et al 1999), the glosses in WordNet are enriched by disambiguating the nouns, verbs, adverbs, and adjectives with synsets

raw_text: In other words, if a synset si is known to be positive (negative), this can be viewed as an indication that the synsets sk to which the terms occurring in the gloss of si belong, are themselves positive (negative) .We obtain the data of the I relation from eXtended WordNet (Harabagiu et al, 1999), an automatically sense-disambiguated version of WordNet in which every term occurrence in every gloss is linked to the synset it is deemed to belong to
clean_text: We obtain the data of the I relation from eXtended WordNet (Harabagiu et al, 1999), an automatically sense-disambiguated version of WordNet in which every term occurrence in every gloss is linked to the synset it is deemed to belong to.

raw_text: 3.2eXtended WordNet The transformation of WordNet into a graph base don the I relation would of course be nontrivial, but is luckily provided by eXtended Word Net (Harabagiu et al, 1999), a publicly available version of WordNet in which (among other things) each term sk occurring in a WordNet gloss (except those in example phrases) is lemmatized and mapped to the synset in which it belongs2
clean_text: The transformation of WordNet into a graph based on the I relation would of course be nontrivial, but is luckily provided by eXtended WordNet (Harabagiu et al, 1999), a publicly available version of WordNet in which (among other things) each term sk occurring in a WordNet gloss (except those in example phrases) is lemmatized and mapped to the synset in which it belongs.

raw_text: TheeXtended WordNet (Harabagiu et al, 1999) project aims to transform the WordNet glosses into a format that allows the derivation of additional semantic and logic relations
clean_text: The eXtended WordNet (Harabagiu et al, 1999) project aims to transform the WordNet glosses into a format that allows the derivation of additional semantic and logic relations.
